title: Great benefits. Workload is overwhelming
pros: Great pay, great benefits. Company wants to create a great culture for their employees. Some really nice people work here.
cons: Overall, the property management profession sucks. Its a thankless, 24/7 job. People are rude and disrespectful. That is pretty much how it goes any company your work for. Big issues here is that leadership is ignorant to the challenges we face. With that being said, there is high expectations from leadership and a lot of pressure (almost to a toxic level). Even though historically, the properties owned in the Midwest region were plagued with deferred maintenance and previous mismanagement. Its hard to catchup to this unrealistic standard and work load when the properties were neglected for so long in the past.

title: Good Pay/ Benefits. Very Toxic managment.

cons: The account specialists are overworked and underappreciated. The VP of the department Accounting/leasing has zero people skills. Was nice enough to send out an e-mail telling everyone they should be lucky to have a job. There is no ownership in any department other than collections. Hated leaving the position and people I worked with, loved leaving the management. they are way too toxic.

title: Great culture, not much room for growth

title: Excellent Culture
pros: very good benefits Summer Incentives Summer Friday (you only work 5 hours) health incentives good medical insurance bonds friendly coworkers good working environment various activities 15 PTO 4 personal days 5 sick days 1 Bday
cons: the salary needs to adjust more to the situation of the country. Other companies pay better, but it is good to compare the benefits

title: Intern
pros: Brixmor cares greatly about work-life balance and their employees.
cons: Working remote 3 days a week made it harder to develop relationships in the office

title: Financial Asset Management = FP&A in the real world
pros: - Open door policy with executive team - Majority of FAM Directors are good to work with - Property management and leasing colleagues are great to work with - Company has flex time, but "FAM" team still required to show up at 9 everyday in order fulfill SVP's yearning desire to show others we are working
cons: - SVP has no prior managerial experience of a big team causing tension and resentment. Questionable hiring by executive management. - After over a year with new management, the processes and procedures for schedules and presentations is still lacking and creates confusion. - SVP does a lot of double talk. Will praise you one day, then sit you down for a talk due to showing up at work at 9:05. - No gratitude toward weekend hours. - There is the ability to take car service home, ONLY if it is within Manhattan city limits. (Makes sense, right?) - Directors make productive suggestions and comments to SVP but falls on deaf ears, unless CFO and CEO make the same suggestions. - Department has a hard time filling vacated roles, with reason. - Redevelopment analysis and presentation is a brutal process, everyone hates doing it, including the many counter parts in other departments. - Being called a Regional "CFO" with no say at the table and no decision making power.

title: Great Company to Work For!
pros: This company has a great atmosphere and culture. The colleagues are all really nice and it is a great place to work. Also it is hybrid work 2 days in, 3 at home.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Job not a career.
pros: Summer fridays IF workload allows (expect to take 4 of the 12 offered). PTO, vacation & benefits average.
cons: Workload is extremely high. Not enough employees to meet the demand. Pay is lower than local average. Worked alot of overtime and not compensated. Still couldn't keep up with work load. Average turnover rate is 2-4 years. Be prepared to not be appreciated and deal with emotionally triggered supervisors. High stress, always made to feel fear of loosing job. Middle management is cut throat. Alot of politics. Zero opportunity for advancement or training in anything useful. Morale is low. Expect raises only to be 2% no value from reviews and bonuses aren't even a week's pay. Expect your work is waiting for you, if you take PTO. Zero ingenuity.

title: Brixmor Leasing Department
pros: Vacation, personal and sick time, summer Friday's, holidays, learned a great deal about leasing and the different aspects of a REIT and loved working the leasing team and most co-workers
cons: hohocken, PA

title: disgusted
pros: Hours great, Benefits great, Perks great
cons: Message of top leadership did not always find its way to bottom of the ladder. Was told for two years - You are doing a good job, but no pay increase for the good job I was doing. And then told three different reasons why I got no pay raise when apparently all others in the company got pay increases. Upper management has no clue of the multiple intricacies of the building I was managing. So, there is a huge disconnect from upper management and the localized worker. No forgiveness in their policy for any oversight - no not any forgiveness.

title: Once a better teaching ground
pros: Was a great way to learn about Real Estate Accounting, Collections, Financial Analysis. It paved for me to commit to other companies with confidence and ease.
cons: Now - one's duties have been stripped that you only know one thing, depending on the department you were in. It doesn't help with growth or in case you get laid off and go to another company because the skill sets aren't there.

title: Manager
pros: PTO benefits; RE Industry;
cons: Base Pay; Communication; Inconsistent skill sets among staff through VPs; Work Flexibility not to market

title: Nice company, horrible operational management staff.
pros: Excellent fellow team members. Company benefits are very good. Salaries are inline with industry standards.
cons: Management isn't supportive and creates a lot of "make work". Inefficiencies abound in the planning and execution of initiative's. Employees are lost in the quagmire of the "my way or the hi-way" attitude. There is little chance your idea's formulated through years of experience and research will be considered or even reviewed. Senior management does not directly or indirectly support the employees by providing direction and/or learning opportunities.

title: Great company and culture
pros: The culture of the company has evolved over the years into one that focuses on training and developing employees professionally and personally, and is constantly looking for ways to do so. The company embraces teamwork and collaboration. I look forward to going to work every day and feel that my opinion is valued and my work is rewarded.
cons: The summer Friday hours aren't the best, but at least we get the perk (and throughout the whole company). I had only hear of this perk for companies in New York City, but Brixmor offers it to all the offices.

title: A great place to work
pros: Great environment to work in as the departments all collaborate. The benefits offered are great between the healthcare, PTO, sick and vacations time. Brixmor does keep in mind that employees have lives outside of work and offer some benefits that make spending time with family that much easier.
cons: hohocken, PA

title: Change for the better
pros: Brixmor has a new executive team that empowers employees and has an open-door policy. That's a good thing for great employees, but there is nowhere to hide if you are below average. Definitely a much-improved culture.
cons: Still getting the team to function seamlessly with many new people, but that will come with time. Benefits are good, but could be more generous.

title: Hard work is recognized
pros: Senior management recognizes hard work and innovative thinking. They appreciate when you come forward with a solution rather than presenting problems that need to be fixed. There's even a quarterly award for this type of thinking. I've seen so much growth over the years, it's great to work for a company that invests in your professional and personal growth.
cons: hohocken, PA

title: Just keep looking...dont stop here.
pros: It used to be the people..but everyone is miserable now since the new CFO started.
cons: hohocken, PA

title: Proud to be a Brixmor Employee
pros: Brixmor's tenet of "great real estate matters, but great people matter more" resonates through the growing benefits and opportunities it offers employees and also through it's continuing efforts to develop its properties, people and processes. It's a great company to learn the business.
cons: Not really a con, but there are regular deadlines that have to be met and you just need to plan. The good thing is you'll know about these in advance.

title: Resume builder, but political nightmare and disorganized
pros: Brixmor has lots of money to spend, and is not afraid to do it for the right deals and tenants. Massive real estate portfolio provides exposure and intelligence across most of the major US markets. Brixmor work experience looks great on your resume. Very strong pay, 37.5 hour work week, and benefits are best in class. Summer Fridays ending at 1pm is great. Colleagues at lower levels tend to be friendly and helpful, but some are problematic due management pitting the departments against each other.
cons: The company is dominated by egocentric and relationship based individuals that naturally create a politically charged environment. Managment lacks leadership and team building skills, and it's a "do as I say, not as I do" type of attitude. Upper management wants control over every inch of the premier deals, and second guesses the employees work on a regular basis. They also assign tasks that consume loads of time that are not critical to completing the core objectives. The whole company lacks executable organization tools. NO REAL ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENT EXISTS. Leasing support tasks and responsibilties of other departments regularly get pushed onto leasing, since the company attitude is that leasing's paycheck depends on completion of these support tasks. Multiple systems all requiring manual entry insures that a lot of errors occur in the system. There is no one single, reliable source for information. It's an "Every man for himself" type of culture, hidden behind a smiling face...

title: Horrible degrading experience!
pros: The pay was decent and the hours were good.
cons: To start off I was not trained properly which ultimately reflected poorly on me with management. I was expected to perform a job that took two people to accomplish in the other regions. Not to mention I experienced daily verbal tirade from my boss. When I reported the incidents to HR it only made matters worse. The next day my boss mentioned my visit to HR and was furious using vulgar language not suited for the workplace. As I left the building for the last time my coworkers decided to speak up. Only it was too late. They mentioned that 9 other women in the last couple of months left my job in tears.

title: Grateful to be part of this organization
pros: Promotes from within, pay for performance environment, great benefits/perks & PTO, very professional and inclusive workplace, leaders believe in and demonstrate the mission and culture tenets via their actions.
cons: Lack of a clear telecommuting policy is a sore spot for many. Some are allowed to work from home/remotely, others not, even if their jobs can easily be done remotely.

title: Lazy Property Managers throw their admins under the bus!
pros: It was great when I was working as a construction admin but then got laid off. Nice office, some perks, good benes.
cons: Abusive property managers, no support from corporate or on site VP's -- they all tend to look the other way. Worked on the weekends because PM's I supported never answered their phones. Also handled month billing -- something they "delegated" to their admins. Thank God after a few years, corp office recognized how lazy they were and fired them.

title: Only if you're desperate
pros: Fruits and bagel wednesday, and the the flex time
cons: hohocken, PA

title: Fast Paced Learning Environment
pros: Previously the company use to give people chances. They trained and promoted people from within.
cons: Management always looks to cut cost at the cost of employees. The saying “everyone gets expensive at some point” isn’t just a saying here and it is a matter of time as pay and/or your title increases.

title: Good Experience
pros: Summer Hours, 37.5 hour work week. Ability to carry over vacation days. Overall was a good experience. There was some issues with leadership and upper management towards the end of my tenure, other than that was a great experience with great people.

title: Brixmor is a great company

cons: Space is a challenge. Hours are not flexible at all. Wanting to be involved and it not being welcomed. All the good outweighs these couple of things.

title: Great Company
pros: Lots of paid vacations, PTO, and sick days, pay is good with tons of benefits. This is the best company I have work for in all my life. Come join us at Brixmor Property Group.

title: Worst company ever
